content.heading: HTML Input Attributes
paragraphs: This chapter describes the different attributes for the HTML <input> element.

content.heading: The value Attribute
paragraphs: The input value attribute specifies an initial value for an input field:

The readonly Attribute
paragraphs: The input readonly attribute specifies that an input field is read-only.
A read-only input field cannot be modified (however, a user can tab to it, highlight it, and copy the text from it).
The value of a read-only input field will be sent when submitting the form!

content.heading: Example
The disabled Attribute
paragraphs: The input disabled attribute specifies that an input field should be disabled.
A disabled input field is unusable and un-clickable.
The value of a disabled input field will not be sent when submitting the form!
Example:

content.heading: Example
The size Attribute
paragraphs: The input size attribute specifies the visible width, in characters, of an input field.
The default value for size is 20.
Note: The size attribute works with the following input types: text, search, tel, url, email, and password.
Example:

content.heading: Example
The maxlength Attribute
paragraphs: The input maxlength attribute specifies the maximum number of characters allowed in an input field.
Note: When a maxlength is set, the input field will not accept more than the specified number of characters.
Example:

content.heading: Example
The min and max Attributes
paragraphs: The input min and max attributes specify the minimum and maximum values for an input field.
These attributes work with number, range, date, datetime-local, month, time, and week input types.
Example:

content.heading: Example
The multiple Attribute
paragraphs: The input multiple attribute specifies that the user is allowed to enter more than one value in an input field.

Example:
<form>
    <label for="files">Select files:</label>
    <input type="file" id="files" name="files" multiple>
</form>

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
<form>
    <label for="files">Select files:</label>
    <input type="file" id="files" name="files" multiple>
</form>

content.heading: The pattern Attribute
paragraphs: The input pattern attribute specifies a regular expression that the input field's value is checked against when the form is submitted.

Example:
<form>
    <label for="country_code">Country code:</label>
    <input type="text" id="country_code" name="country_code" pattern="[A-Za-z]{3}" title="Three letter country code">
</form>

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
<form>
    <label for="country_code">Country code:</label>
    <input type="text" id="country_code" name="country_code" pattern="[A-Za-z]{3}" title="Three letter country code">
</form>

content.heading: The placeholder Attribute
paragraphs: The input placeholder attribute specifies a short hint that describes the expected value of an input field.

Example:
<form>
    <label for="phone">Enter a phone number:</label>
    <input type="tel" id="phone" name="phone" placeholder="123-45-678" pattern="[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{3}">
</form>

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
<form>
    <label for="phone">Enter a phone number:</label>
    <input type="tel" id="phone" name="phone" placeholder="123-45-678" pattern="[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{3}">
</form>

content.heading: The required Attribute
paragraphs: The input required attribute specifies that an input field must be filled out before submitting the form.

Example:
<form>
    <label for="username">Username:</label>
    <input type="text" id="username" name="username" required>
</form>

content.heading: The step Attribute
paragraphs: The input step attribute specifies the legal number intervals for an input field.

Example:
<form>
    <label for="points">Points:</label>
    <input type="number" id="points" name="points" step="3">
</form>
Note: Input restrictions are not foolproof, and JavaScript provides many ways to add illegal input.

The list Attribute
paragraphs: The input list attribute refers to a <datalist> element that contains pre-defined options for an <input> element.

Example:
<form>
    <input list="browsers">
    <datalist id="browsers">
        <option value="Edge">
        <option value="Firefox">
        <option value="Chrome">
        <option value="Opera">
        <option value="Safari">
    </datalist>
</form>
